review.title: Multi-task GLOH feature selection for human age estimation
review.abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel age estimation method based on GLOH feature descriptor and multi-task learning (MTL). The GLOH feature descriptor, one of the state-of-the-art feature descriptor, is used to capture the age-related local and spatial information of face image. As the exacted GLOH features are often redundant, MTL is designed to select the most informative feature bins for age estimation problem, while the corresponding weights are determined by ridge regression. This approach largely reduces the dimensions of feature, which can not only improve performance but also decrease the computational burden. Experiments on the public available FG-NET database show that the proposed method can achieve comparable performance over previous approaches while using much fewer features.

metadata.title: MULTI-TASK GLOH FEATURE SELECTION FOR HUMAN AGE ESTIMATION

sections.text: Index Terms - Age Assessment, GLOH Feature, Multitask Learning, Burr Regression

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: In the last decade, automatic age assessment has become an active research topic.

sections.heading: 2. GLOH REPRESENTATION
sections.text: The local GLOH descriptor, originally introduced by Mikolajczyk et al. [15], was designed to increase the robustness and distinctiveness of the well-known SIFT descriptor, which integrates both local appearance and position information. Simi-ar Xiv: 110 2.27 49v2 [cs.CV] 6 May 201 1lar to the SIFT descriptor, or HOG descriptor, is also based on the evaluation of well-normalized local histograms of image progression orientations in a dense grid. Specifically, the original GLOH descriptor can be achieved by calculating the SIFT or HOG descriptor for a log-polar position grid with three radii and eight angles. Gradient orientations are then quantified into 16 parts, and the resulting descriptor gives a 272-bins histogram that splits the GLOH intersection.

sections.heading: 3. MULTI-TASK GLOH FEATURE SELECTION
sections.text: In fact, it is the case that we will be able to solve the problem in the way that we are going to solve it and in the way that we are going to solve it. (...) sections.heading: 4. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text: We conduct experiments on the FG-NET aging database [18] to verify the proposed age estimation method. The database includes 1, 002 images (82 people) ages 0 to 69. Firstly, we align all images into the middle shape, the aligned face images will be at the size of 68 × 62. During the GLOH feature extraction step, the size of the image patch is set to 10 × 10. For each image patch, we use 3 radius {2, 3} and the 8 gradient directions used in each image patch, so that the dimension of the resulting histogram vector is 136. By concatenating all patches histogram vector, we obtain a 48,960-dimensional original GLOH feature vector. It contains both the local texture and the space information of the face image. By concatenating all patches histogram vector, we obtain a 48,960-dimensional original GLOH feature vector.

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed a novel framework for age assessment based on the GLOH feature and the MTL. By using the GLOH feature to visualize the face image and by multi-task learning to select features, we can select some informative feature bins for age assessment. To confirm the weights of the selected feature bins, the Ridge regression was applied.

sections.heading: 6. ACKNOWLEDGEMENT
sections.text: This research is partially supported by the National Science Fund of China (60803024, 60970098 and 60903136), the Specialized Research Fund for the Doctoral Program of Higher Education (200805331107 and 20090162110055), the Basic Research Fund for Central Universities (201021200062), the Hunan Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China (10JJ6088), the Open Project Program of the State Key Lab of CAD & CG, the University of Zhejiang (A0911 and A1011).

sections.heading: 7. REFERENCES
sections.text: [1] Fu Y., Guo G., and Huang T.S., "Age synthesis and estimation via faces: A survey," IEEE Trans. Pattern Anal. Mach. Intell., vol. 32, pp. 1955-1976, 2010. [2] Y.H. Kwon and N.V. Lobo, "Age classification from facial images," Compu. Vis. Image Understand., vol. 74, pp. 1-21, 1999. [3] A. Lanitis, C.J. Taylor, and T.F. Cootes, "Toward automatic simulation of aging on face images," IEEE Trans. Pattern Anal. Mach. Intell., vol. 24, pp. 422-455, 2002. [4] A. Lanitis, C. Draganova C., and C. Christodoulou., "Comparing different classifiers for automatic age estimation."

referenceMentions.context: Two keys to these methods are face representation and age estimation [1].

Existing face representation techniques for age estimation often include the anthropometric models [2], active appearance models [3, 4, 5], aging pattern subspace [6], age manifold [7, 1, 8], local features such as local binary patterns (LBP) features [9], Gabor features [10], spatially fexible patch (SFP) [11], bio-inspired features (BIF) [12], etc.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we propose a novel age estimation method based on gradient location and orientation histogram (GLOH) descriptor and multi-task learning (MTL). The GLOH, one of the state-of-the-art local descriptor, is used to capture the agerelated local and spatial information of face image. As the extracted GLOH features are often redundant, MTL is designed to select the most informative GLOH bins for age estimation problem, while the corresponding weights are determined by ridge regression. This approach largely reduces the dimensions of feature, which can not only improve performance but also decrease the computational burden. Experiments on the public available FG-NET database show that the proposed method can achieve comparable performance over previous approaches while using much fewer features.
